medical: INDICATIONS: Previously markedly abnormal dobutamine Myoview stress test and gated scan. PROCEDURE DONE: Resting Myoview perfusion scan and gated myocardial scan. MYOCARDIAL PERFUSION IMAGING: Resting myocardial perfusion SPECT imaging and gated scan were carried out with 32.6 mCi of Tc-99m Myoview. Rest study was done and compared to previous dobutamine Myoview stress test done on Month DD, YYYY. The lung heart ratio is 0.34. There appears to be a moderate size inferoapical perfusion defect of moderate degree. The gated myocardial scan revealed mild apical and distal inferoseptal hypokinesis with ejection fraction of 55%. CONCLUSIONS: Study done at rest only revealed findings consistent with an inferior non-transmural scar of moderate size and moderate degree. The left ventricular systolic function is markedly improved with much better regional wall motion of all left ventricular segments when compared to previous study done on Month DD, YYYY. We cannot assess the presence of any reversible perfusion defects because no stress imaging was performed.
layman:
**Reason for the test:**  
You had a previous dobutamine Myoview stress test and gated scan that showed significant problems.

**What was done:**  
A resting Myoview perfusion scan and gated myocardial scan were performed.

**Findings from the resting scan:**  
- The scan used 32.6 mCi of Tc‑99m Myoview.  
- The results were compared to your earlier dobutamine Myoview stress test (done on Month DD, YYYY).  
- The lung‑heart ratio was 0.34.  
- There is a moderate‑sized perfusion defect in the inferoapical area of the heart.  
- The gated scan shows mild movement problems (hypokinesis) at the apex and the far part of the inferoseptal wall.  
- Your ejection fraction (the amount of blood pumped out of the heart with each beat) is 55%.

**Conclusion:**  
The resting study shows a moderate‑sized, non‑transmural scar in the inferior part of the heart.  
Your left ventricular systolic function has improved a lot, with better movement in all left ventricular segments compared to the previous study (Month DD, YYYY).  
Because no stress imaging was done, we cannot determine if there are any reversible perfusion defects.
